item.title: Is Pok√©mon Finally Cooked?
item.content:encoded:
This weekend is a big one for fans and players of competitive Pok√©mon. Thousands of fans are gathering in the Anaheim Convention Center to watch the best of the best battle each other in Scarlet and Violet. However, not everyone is there to have a good time. For some people, the cost of attendance is merely a business expense. Like every other Pok√©mon event or collaboration in recent memory, scalpers have descended upon Anaheim to buy up exclusive Pok√©mon merch and then sell it for a profit. I really wanted to go to Worlds this year, as I‚Äôve been a Pok√©mon fan most of my life and still haven‚Äôt been to one of the championship competitions, but while the tournament is just beginning, the vibes seem so rancid I‚Äôm not sure it would make for a great first impression.

It seems like every other week we here at Kotaku are writing about some absolute nonsense in the Pok√©mon community, as scalpers have made full-time jobs out of buying up cards and collectibles for a quick buck. The controversial practice has become so lucrative for these grown-ass adults that sales devolve into actual acts of violence or crowds end up jockeying to rummage through shelves like it‚Äôs Black Friday. Part of me feels some sympathy for people who have to resort to this because times are tough and it‚Äôs easier than hard labor, but especially considering this franchise has probably brought me more joy than any other for most of my life, it really sucks to see that every new event or merch drop now makes me feel so deeply cynical.

The Anaheim event has only been going on for a day, and there are already reports of resellers setting up shop in neighboring hotels near the convention center, with others responding by putting up signage prohibiting such wheeling and dealing. Competitive players are posting on social media about selling merchandise for more than they paid for it. What is supposed to be a giant community gathering has become something else entirely, and it‚Äôs made it harder to be a fan when you can‚Äôt even engage with it without having to push through people with bad intentions.

I really really dislike how pokemon worlds has turned from a celebration of competitive pokemon to taking anything remotely valuable and scalping it for a profit.

‚Äî Tyson Bl√§tter (@T_Blatt) August 14, 2025

Worlds Pokemon Center showing us once again that capitalism ruins everything people love üôÇ

‚Äî Sawyer Melban (@sawyerhatemail) August 14, 2025

I don‚Äôt understand why some people are complaining that we brought our daughter to the Pokemon Center yesterday. This is literally a family game. We should be able to go in there without people bumping into our stroller and smacking my baby in the face with their shopping bags.‚Ä¶

‚Äî Michele Lesage (@M_LesagePTCG) August 14, 2025

Attending the Pok√©mon Center is genuinely a safety risk due to all the shoving and fighting over product that's going on

It's shameful and ridiculous that we as a community have devolved to the point that this behavior is commonplace.

Shame on all of you acting this way.

‚Äî PokeDuels (@PokeDuelsTikTok) August 14, 2025

Attendees are reporting a better experience at the Worlds shop today, but it‚Äôs hard to wash off the stench scalpers leave when every event has some horror story attached to it in which people who aren‚Äôt even fans show up to take advantage of those who are. So it begs the question: Is Pok√©mon just cooked as a hobby now? After nearly 30 years, has the franchise‚Äôs reputation become so sullied by people who buy its merchandise just to sell it to other people that longtime devotees are leaving it behind? The Pok√©mon franchise is too far-reaching to really be affected by this phenomenon, which a lot of collectors believe is why The Pok√©mon Company doesn‚Äôt do much to really stop it. Purchase limits on new merchandise are helpful, but they don‚Äôt stop scalpers from showing up before stores put cards on the shelf, making multiple accounts to purchase items online, or causing a ruckus at events like Worlds.

You would think constantly being in the headlines for robberies, chaotic sales, and even actual violence associated with your product would be damaging enough to the brand that TPC would be motivated to take real action. But again, Pok√©mon is so prolific that TPC doesn‚Äôt actually receive any chip damage from this. A sale to a scalper puts the same amount of money in Pikachu‚Äôs pockets as one to a devoted fan. The assembly line will keep going, and unless people stop buying from them, scalpers will keep showing up. As I said earlier, Pok√©mon has brought me more joy than probably any other series. These days, however, that joy is getting drowned out by cynicism every time some event takes place that should be reminding me why I fell in love with Pok√©mon in the first place.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-tcg-plush-scalper-reseller-world-championships-2000618087

item.title: So, Uh, Is It Worth Playing FBC: Firebreak Right Now?
item.content:encoded:
• What don‚Äôt folks like about FBC: Firebreak?
  • How many people are playing right now?
  • Does FBC: Firebreak have crossplay support?
  • Does FBC: Firebreak have cross-progression support?

The Remedy Connected Universe is growing pretty rapidly these days, and its latest entry is a Control spin-off known as FBC: Firebreak. In this cooperative shooter, players return to the Federal Bureau of Control‚Äôs bizarre and unsettling Oldest House with up to two pals.

Read More: Alan Wake Devs Plan A Big Relaunch For Failing Co-Op Flop

Unfortunately, the game hasn‚Äôt been the hit many were probably hoping for. Developer Remedy is looking to put some elbow grease into rehabilitating the co-op shooter. But you can play it right now if you want. So let‚Äôs get into everything you‚Äôd need to know if you want to play it as of summer 2025.

What don‚Äôt folks like about FBC: Firebreak?

Firebreak unfortunately hasn‚Äôt satisfied critics or players. Cited issues include a ‚Äúlifeless‚Äù feeling when playing and a bit too much chaos and drudgery. It‚Äôs a disappointing debut for a game set in an otherwise excellent setting with a decent premise.

How many people are playing right now?

While you may be able to make your own fun in Firebreak, it‚Äôs fair to say most people aren‚Äôt. At the time of this writing, SteamDB reports a player count in the low teens, with an all-time peak of 1,992 players. Those aren‚Äôt great numbers on PC, to say the least.

Does FBC: Firebreak have crossplay support?

The short answer is yes, FBC: Firebreak has crossplay support. Players can team with one another across other platforms by sharing a party code. So, if you‚Äôre a console fan with friends who prefer to play on PC, or vice versa, you can invite each other for some first-person shooting fun in either duos or trios.

Does FBC: Firebreak have cross-progression support?

The good news stops at crossplay, I‚Äôm afraid. FBC: Firebreak does not support cross-progression at launch.

However, that doesn‚Äôt mean the game won‚Äôt have cross-progression at some point in the future.

Speaking to MP1ST, community manager Julian Fondum responded to an inquiry about cross-progression by saying, ‚ÄúNot at launch. Maybe way down the line. It‚Äôs a maybe. A lot of things we‚Äôre doing on the back end [are] definitely built in the way that we can do a bunch of things down the line when we have more resources and so on.‚Äù

That sounds promising to me! But as with any feature that hasn‚Äôt been confirmed yet, don‚Äôt hold your breath. I suspect there are plenty of things on the game‚Äôs roadmap that Remedy views as more pivotal for the game than this for now.

If you‚Äôre a fan of the Remedy Connected Universe and want to see what all the fuss is about, even if the game has failed to impress on launch, FBC: Firebreak is available now on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series S/X, and Windows PCs.



https://kotaku.com/fbc-firebreak-remedy-alan-wake-control-oldest-house-2000618046

item.title: Mafia: The Old Country Is Getting A Real Open-World Mode
item.content:encoded:
Mafia: The Old Country isn‚Äôt an open-world game like some of the previous titles in the franchise. Instead, it‚Äôs a linear action game set inside large, detailed areas that offer some freedom. However, a new upcoming update will add a more traditional open-world mode to the recently released game.

On August 14, developer Hangar 13 posted a message on social media thanking players for all the ‚Äúlove and loyalty‚Äù following the launch of Mafia: The Old Country earlier this month. But the message also contained an announcement: The Old Country will get a ‚ÄúFree Ride‚Äù mode in a free future update.

‚ÄúToday, we‚Äôre excited to confirm Free Ride is on its way,‚Äù posted Hangar 13 on Twitter. ‚ÄúExpect some new activities and gameplay, arriving free for all players in the coming months.‚Äù

Mafiosi‚Äîthanks for the love and loyalty you've shown #MafiaTheOldCountry since launch.

Today, we're excited to confirm ùêÖùê´ùêûùêû ùêëùê¢ùêùùêû is on its way! Expect some new activities and gameplay, arriving free for all players in the coming months. pic.twitter.com/FqJ3UU9brG

‚Äî Mafia Game (@mafiagame) August 14, 2025

Currently, Mafia: The Old Country does include a ‚ÄúFree Roam‚Äù option known as Exploration, but this mode is pretty boring and doesn‚Äôt feature enemies, missions, activities, or much to do. You can find and grab missed collectibles and clean up some other loose ends, but for the most part, it‚Äôs an empty world devoid of anything to do. That won‚Äôt be the case with this new open-world-esque ‚ÄúFree Ride‚Äù mode. And while we don‚Äôt have any more details about Free Ride in Old Country just yet, we can look at the most recent release in the series to see what to expect.

Free Ride was a mode present in Mafia: The Definitive Edition, Hangar 13‚Äôs remastered version of the original Mafia game released back in 2020. It let players run around the game‚Äôs city and countryside freely and added new missions, races, and even some wackier content involving rituals and aliens. It was unlocked after beating the first mission in the game. I would assume Free Ride in Old Country will be similar in scope and scale. If that‚Äôs the case, many players who missed the more open-world format of Mafia III will be happy to have something bigger and more free-roaming to sink their teeth into when it arrives at some unspecified date in the ‚Äúcoming months.‚Äù



https://kotaku.com/mafia-the-old-country-is-getting-a-real-open-world-mode-2000618051

item.title: Mouthwashing Fans Are Tearing Each Other Apart Over A Cat Plush
item.content:encoded:
When I played Mouthwashing, Wrong Organ‚Äôs psychological horror game and surprise dark horse in the 2024 Game of the Year race, I couldn‚Äôt have anticipated it would reach the level of fandom in which it got cute, marketable plushies. Its subject matter is very dark, but then again, that‚Äôs never really stopped horror games and movies from going down this path. I suppose it shouldn‚Äôt be too surprising, then, that its characters are getting stuffed toys, despite the terrible things they all go through in Mouthwashing‚Äôs brief runtime. What is surprising is that after all this time, the community is not only still debating the game‚Äôs horrors and morality‚Ä¶but now, they‚Äôve devolved into going for each other‚Äôs throats over a plush of a character named Jimmy reimagined as a cute cat.

Content warning: Sexual assault

Jimmy is the primary player character in Mouthwashing. He and his crew have been stranded in space after their freight ship collided with an asteroid, and the game goes over the fallout of the crash and the months that followed. Without getting too into everything that goes down, suffice it to say Mouthwashing is a pretty harrowing story involving some of the worst things humans are capable of, and Jimmy is the perpetrator of a lot of those crimes. He‚Äôs also an unreliable narrator attempting to cover up what he‚Äôs done, and the things he‚Äôs revealed to have done on the ship put him far beyond any possible redemption. 

Jimmy does a lot of reprehensible things in Mouthwashing, and the one that‚Äôs perhaps most notable is that the game implies he raped Anya, the lone woman on the ship, who is now pregnant. We don‚Äôt need to get into all the repercussions of this act here, but as you can imagine, a lot of Mouthwashing fans are not fans of Jimmy‚Äôs. In fact, I‚Äôd argue the game‚Äôs entire point is to make you hate this guy. He‚Äôs the villain of this story, and even if he attempts to do the right thing at the end of the game, that‚Äôs not going to be enough for some. Others, meanwhile, do find him compelling as a character whose layered story has a lot of depth. For some who find his actions unforgivable, even believing him an interesting centerpiece in Mouthwashing‚Äôs story goes beyond what they believe to be morally acceptable.

Fast forward to August 2025, and a collectible manufacturer called Plushshop is making a cat-shaped plush of Jimmy. The store has stuffed cats based on characters from anime, TV shows, and video games, ranging from Squid Game to One Piece. When the company first announced plans to make Mouthwashing plushes, those plans didn‚Äôt include one for Jimmy, which led to backlash from fans. The company has since removed those initial Mouthwashing plushes from its store and deleted any mention of them from its social media accounts.

However, after the shop announced its Jimmy plush as a separate launch, Mouthwashing fans jumped on the website to leave negative user reviews saying that given Jimmy‚Äôs true nature, he shouldn‚Äôt be made into a cute cat plush. That alone is maybe a conversation worth having, but the comments quickly devolved into a toxic cesspool, with some people claiming that those who bought the plush were rape apologists and several comments that, for some reason, included racial slurs. I went to go look at them myself on PlusShop‚Äôs website, but the Jimmy plush seems to have been removed. We‚Äôve reached out to PlushShop for comment on the situation and will update the story if we hear back. In the meantime, screenshots of the reviews have begun circulating on places like X (formerly Twitter) and Reddit, but do be warned that there‚Äôs some foul language in those links. 

As someone who really enjoyed Mouthwashing for its exploration of the human psyche and its striking visuals, am I thrilled that its characters are being made into plushes? Not particularly. I do think it‚Äôs a bit weird to make those characters cute cats or even just regular toys. It turns a pretty horrific story into an almost absurdist display prop, and even the officially licensed plush of a man wrapped up in bandages with his painkillers made into an accessory kind of feels like a parody or shitpost, turning some of the most memorable, horrific imagery in the game into a purchasable gag. All that said, the reaction to this cat plush is so ludicrously overblown and reeks of the kind of ‚Äúputting fictional characters on trial‚Äù nonsense that has plagued discussions around games like The Last of Us or Nier and that I can‚Äôt believe we‚Äôre still dealing with in 2025.

Good stories are built around conflict, and in some of those stories, the perpetrators of that conflict are reprehensible people who cannot be redeemed in the eyes of the beholder. Yes, in Mouthwashing, one character has committed one of the most vile things a person is capable of. But he is not a real person, and he is not on trial. Liking a story in which people do terrible things is not the same as endorsing their actions, and if that goes over someone‚Äôs head, I‚Äôm surprised they‚Äôre engaging with Mouthwashing to begin with considering several of its characters are morally dubious, to say the least. Since some of the comments weighing in on this use racial slurs, I imagine at least some of those people putting Jimmy on trial have larger issues than a lack of media literacy. 

The root of these kinds of arguments is that there will always be people who don‚Äôt understand that others engage with art differently than they do. One thing I‚Äôve learned in my years of writing, reading, watching, and listening to criticism is that you‚Äôll find that there are some people who have different expectations when they voice an opinion about a work. For example, when someone lashes out at a critique, it‚Äôs often under the pretense that a critic is trying to ‚Äúchange‚Äù something they think is fine. When some fans voice a complaint about a game, they expect the developers to address it in a patch, and so when they see another person criticizing anything, this is the only framework they have for understanding that critique: as, effectively, a complaint to management over an issue they wish to see rectified.

The same thing happens with how people engage with characters. Some people only ‚Äúlike‚Äù characters if they support everything they do and can stand by them in the end, so the concept of enjoying a character who does reprehensible shit is so foreign to them that it is somehow a moral failing to derive any sort of satisfaction from them, even from dissecting their actions. Because people are so fixated on their own media literacy framework, art that engages in uncomfortable topics will never be free from Tumblr-era moralizing. To people who make these arguments, ‚Äúproblematic‚Äù storylines are just problems to be solved, rather than a means of exploring potentially challenging or uncomfortable themes. The curtains were blue. Jimmy was a bad guy. That‚Äôs all there is to it.

I didn‚Äôt expect to rant about this on a random Friday in August, and I certainly didn‚Äôt expect it to be over a toy cat. I really enjoyed Mouthwashing, but I guess it‚Äôs a good thing I didn‚Äôt get too involved with its community, because it sure seems like there are a lot of people in that community who are ill-equipped to engage with the game they‚Äôre purportedly fans of.



https://kotaku.com/mouthwashing-jimmy-cat-plush-jimmymeow-plushshop-2000618052
